gear.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the machinery in a vehicle such as a car, truck, or bicycle that you use to go comfortably at different speeds
gear.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Andy drove cautiously along in third gear.
Does this thing have a reverse gear?
Any cyclist can climb a difficult hill; you just change gear.
Don’t turn off the engine while you’re still in gear.
It’s a good habit to take the car out of gear while you’re at a stoplight.
gear.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used to talk about the amount of effort and energy that someone is using in a situation
gear.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: During this period, Japan’s export industries were in top gear (=were as active as they could be).
The Republican’s propaganda machine moved into high gear.
United stepped up a gear in the second half.
gear.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a set of equipment or tools you need for a particular activity
gear.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: He’s crazy about photography – he’s got all the gear.
gear.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a set of clothes that you wear for a particular occasion or activity
gear.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: a piece of machinery that performs a particular job
gear.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: the landing gear of a plane
gear.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a word meaning illegal drugs, used by people who take drugs
gear.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: first/second/third etc gear
The heavy traffic meant that we seldom got out of second gear.
a low gear
You should use a low gear when going up a hill.
a high gear
Put the car into a higher gear.
top gear
Hamilton slipped effortlessly into top gear.
bottom gear
The car trundled slowly forward in bottom gear.
reverse gear
He put the truck into reverse gear.
change gear
It takes some time to learn when to change gear.
put the car etc into (first/second/third etc) gear
He put the car into gear, and they moved slowly forwards.
engage first/second etc gear
Nick struggled to engage first gear.
be in the wrong gear
The straining noises from the engine told him that he was in the wrong gear.
crunch/grind the gears
He crunched the gears into reverse.
gear.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: special equipment or clothing used for a particular purpose
gear.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: We manufacture airplane landing gear and other aerospace parts.
Police in riot gear (=special clothing that protects them if they are attacked) stopped demonstrators getting anywhere near the G8 conference.
gear.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if an activity moves into high gear, it becomes much more important, and people put more effort into making it succeed
gear.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The alliance with Mattel is part of Disney’s strategy to keep its merchandising efforts in top gear.
gear.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: if a financial or industrial activity is in low gear, it is not growing, or it is not at a high level
gear.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: The country’s economy has been stuck in low gear since 1992.
Wall Street shifted into low gear (=started working more slowly than usual) ahead of the Memorial Day weekend.
gear.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to be designed or organized in a way that is suitable for a particular purpose
gear.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Fiji’s policies are geared towards reducing reliance on sugar exports and tourism.
Honda’s latest advertisements are geared at consumers who normally prefer buying American trucks and cars.
gear.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to be connected to something, so that if one thing changes, so does the other
gear.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: They were borrowing large sums that weregeared to interest rates that might rise.
The minimum notice period is geared to the length of time you have been employed.
